title: Reflection on the Use of GenAI
text:
For this assessment, I primarily used ChatGPT. I chose it mainly because it’s the primary GenAI tool that I’m already familiar with and use regularly.



ChatGPT was particularly helpful when I encountered technical issues. For example:
GitHub Authentication Problem: Initially, I had problems with my GitHub because I was previously logged in with my personal email and later changed to my school email. This caused a clash, and I wasn’t able to push my files to GitHub. ChatGPT provided me with solution recommendations, which was extremely useful as I wouldn’t have known what to do otherwise.
Other Assistance Included: - Explaining Quarto and GitHub Pages setup - Providing markdown formatting examples - Troubleshooting R code errors - Suggesting content structure for different pages



The tool really helped with reducing stress and panic. I know I would have panicked much more when things went wrong, and I would have spent significantly more time researching on Google for possible solutions. ChatGPT provided quick, targeted assistance that saved me time and reduced anxiety.



One significant challenge with using ChatGPT is ensuring information accuracy, as the AI sometimes provides solutions that are outdated or don’t work in practice, requiring me to verify suggestions and try multiple approaches. Additionally, the tool lacks context understanding—it cannot see my screen or know my exact setup, so even with specific descriptions, it occasionally misunderstands my situation and offers irrelevant advice. There’s also a risk of over-reliance; I had to consciously balance seeking AI help with developing my own troubleshooting skills to avoid dependency. Another issue is that responses can be too generic, missing the nuances of my specific problems and necessitating repeated follow-up questions. Finally, there’s a learning curve for effective prompting—I needed to learn how to phrase questions precisely to obtain useful answers, as poorly worded queries often led to confusing or unhelpful responses.



I think GenAI would serve as a form of confirmation for me - a way I can double-check my work before submitting. It could also assist with planning and brainstorming ideas. In future studies and work, I envision using it for:

Quick validations of my approaches
Brainstorming sessions when starting new projects
Error checking in code and documents
Learning explanations for complex topics
Template generation for reports and presentations




Using GenAI for this assessment was like having a knowledgeable assistant available 24/7. While it couldn’t solve every problem perfectly, it significantly reduced my stress and helped me overcome technical hurdles more efficiently. The key lesson was learning to use it as a tool rather than a crutch - taking its suggestions as starting points but applying my own judgment and understanding.
The experience showed me that GenAI is most effective when combined with human critical thinking. It provides options and possibilities, but I need to evaluate, adapt, and implement the solutions that work best for my specific context.

title: Welcome to My Personal Website!
text:
SIT Logo



Hi! I’m Sharlene
Applied Computing Student
Singapore Institute of Technology




This website showcases my journey through Applied Computing at SIT, featuring technical projects, data analysis work, and reflections on modern development tools.



FYP Project – Queue system development for large-scale events
Data Visualization – Healthcare data analysis with actionable insights

AI Reflection – Learning experiences with generative AI tools

This site is continuously updated as I progress through my studies at SIT.

title: Data Visualization: Dengue in Singapore
text:
Dengue Cases 2019-2024


Annual dengue cases in Singapore (Source: NEA)
Note: I previously created a detailed line chart visualization of dengue case trends, analyzing seasonal patterns and outbreak correlations. While that specific chart file isn’t available on my current device, this numerical data represents the same analysis I conducted on Singapore’s dengue situation and its healthcare implications.



People are hospitalized for dengue due to: - Severe symptoms: High fever, bleeding, organ impairment - Dengue Shock Syndrome: Life-threatening drop in blood pressure - High-risk groups: Elderly, pregnant women, chronic illness patients - Dehydration: Requires IV fluids and monitoring




Bed occupancy: Sudden surges strain hospital capacity
Resource allocation: Diverts staff from other departments
Cost burden: Estimated $10,000+ per hospitalized patient
Preventive costs: NEA spends millions on mosquito control annually





NEA surveillance: Regular inspections and fogging
Public education: “Do the Mozzie Wipeout” campaigns
Community reporting: MyENV app for breeding site alerts
Vaccination: For eligible at-risk populations





Peak in 2020/2022: Weather patterns + reduced control during COVID
Low in 2021: Movement restrictions limited mosquito breeding
2024 estimate: Shows ongoing challenge despite control measures
Pattern: Dengue remains cyclical, requiring constant vigilance

Insight: Singapore’s healthcare succeeds in managing outbreaks through integrated prevention and rapid response systems.

title: FYP Project: NYP Open House Queue System
text:
Institution: Nanyang Polytechnic
Course: Business and Financial Technology
Year: September 2024 - November 2025


Developed a queue management system for luggage tag customization and collection during NYP’s 2025 Open House. This queue-based system digitalized the visitor flow process to improve efficiency and user experience.




Virtual queue system via QR codes
Luggage tag customization interface
Automated notification for collection
Real-time queue monitoring dashboard





Frontend: HTML, CSS, JavaScript
Backend: Python, Full Stack Development
Database: SQLite





Reduced wait times by 65%
Processed 500+ tags over 2 days
Positive feedback from visitors and staff

How NYP Open House typically looks:
 Video Source: YouTube - Nanyang Polytechnic
